trans-unit.source: My first graphical runbook in Azure Automation
trans-unit.target: My first graphical runbook in Azure Automation

trans-unit.source: Tutorial that walks you through the creation, testing, and publishing of a simple graphical runbook. Several concepts are covered such as authenticating to Azure resources, input parameters, and conditional links.
trans-unit.target: Tutorial that walks you through the creation, testing, and publishing of a simple graphical runbook. Several concepts are covered such as authenticating to Azure resources, input parameters, and conditional links.

trans-unit.source: My first graphical runbook
trans-unit.target: My first graphical runbook

trans-unit.source: This tutorial walks you through the creation of a <link><linkText>graphical runbook</linkText><title></title></link> in Azure Automation.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial walks you through the creation of a <link><linkText>graphical runbook</linkText><title></title></link> in Azure Automation.

trans-unit.source: We'll start with a simple runbook that we'll test and publish while we explain how to track the status of the runbook job.
trans-unit.target: We'll start with a simple runbook that we'll test and publish while we explain how to track the status of the runbook job.

trans-unit.source: Then we'll modify the runbook to actually manage Azure resources, in this case starting an Azure virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Then we'll modify the runbook to actually manage Azure resources, in this case starting an Azure virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: We'll then make the runbook more robust by adding runbook parameters and a conditional link.
trans-unit.target: We'll then make the runbook more robust by adding runbook parameters and a conditional link.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you will need the following.
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you will need the following.

trans-unit.source: Azure subscription. If you don't have one yet, you can <link><linkText>activate your MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title></link> or <html></html><link><linkText>sign up for a free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Azure subscription. If you don't have one yet, you can <link><linkText>activate your MSDN subscriber benefits</linkText><title></title></link> or <html></html><link><linkText>sign up for a free trial</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Automation account</linkText><title></title></link> to hold the runbook.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Automation account</linkText><title></title></link> to hold the runbook.

trans-unit.source: An Azure virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: An Azure virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: We will stop and start this machine so it should not be production.
trans-unit.target: We will stop and start this machine so it should not be production.

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure Active Directory user and Automation Credential asset</linkText><title></title></link> to authenticate to Azure resources.
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure Active Directory user and Automation Credential asset</linkText><title></title></link> to authenticate to Azure resources.

trans-unit.source: This user must have permission to start and stop the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This user must have permission to start and stop the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Step 1 - Create new runbook
trans-unit.target: Step 1 - Create new runbook

trans-unit.source: We'll start by creating a simple runbook that outputs the text Hello World.
trans-unit.target: We'll start by creating a simple runbook that outputs the text Hello World.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Preview Portal, open your Automation account.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Preview Portal, open your Automation account.

trans-unit.source: The Automation account page gives you a quick view of the resources in this account.
trans-unit.target: The Automation account page gives you a quick view of the resources in this account.

trans-unit.source: You should already have some Assets.
trans-unit.target: You should already have some Assets.

trans-unit.source: Most of those are the modules that are automatically included in a new Automation account.
trans-unit.target: Most of those are the modules that are automatically included in a new Automation account.

trans-unit.source: You should also have the Credential asset that's mentioned in the <link><linkText>prerequisites</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You should also have the Credential asset that's mentioned in the <link><linkText>prerequisites</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Click on the Runbooks tile to open the list of runbooks.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Runbooks tile to open the list of runbooks.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Runbooks control</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Runbooks control</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Create a new runbook by clicking on the Add a runbook button and then Create a new runbook.
trans-unit.target: Create a new runbook by clicking on the Add a runbook button and then Create a new runbook.

trans-unit.source: Give the runbook the name MyFirstRunbook-Graphical.
trans-unit.target: Give the runbook the name MyFirstRunbook-Graphical.

trans-unit.source: In this case, we're going to create a graphical runbook so select Graphical for Runbook type.
trans-unit.target: In this case, we're going to create a graphical runbook so select Graphical for Runbook type.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New runbook</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New runbook</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Create to create the runbook and open the graphical editor.
trans-unit.target: Click Create to create the runbook and open the graphical editor.

trans-unit.source: Step 2 - Add activities to the runbook
trans-unit.target: Step 2 - Add activities to the runbook

trans-unit.source: The Library control on the left side of the editor allows you to select activities add to your runbook.
trans-unit.target: The Library control on the left side of the editor allows you to select activities add to your runbook.

trans-unit.source: We're going to add a Write-Output cmdlet to output our text from the runbook.
trans-unit.target: We're going to add a Write-Output cmdlet to output our text from the runbook.

trans-unit.source: In the Library control, expand the Cmdlets node and then Microsoft.PowerShell.Utility.
trans-unit.target: In the Library control, expand the Cmdlets node and then Microsoft.PowerShell.Utility.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Microsoft.PowerShell.Utility</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Microsoft.PowerShell.Utility</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Scroll down to the bottom of the list.
trans-unit.target: Scroll down to the bottom of the list.

trans-unit.source: Right click Write-Output and click Add to canvas.
trans-unit.target: Right click Write-Output and click Add to canvas.

trans-unit.source: Click on the Write-Output activity on the canvas.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Write-Output activity on the canvas.

trans-unit.source: This opens the Configuration control which allows you to configure the activity.
trans-unit.target: This opens the Configuration control which allows you to configure the activity.

trans-unit.source: The Label defaults to the name of the cmdlet, but we can change it to something more friendly.
trans-unit.target: The Label defaults to the name of the cmdlet, but we can change it to something more friendly.

trans-unit.source: Change it to Write Hello World to output.
trans-unit.target: Change it to Write Hello World to output.

trans-unit.source: Click Parameters to provide values for the cmdlet's parameters.
trans-unit.target: Click Parameters to provide values for the cmdlet's parameters.

trans-unit.source: Some cmdlets have multiple parameter sets, and you need to select which you will use. In this case, Write-Output has only one parameter set, so you don't need to select one.
trans-unit.target: Some cmdlets have multiple parameter sets, and you need to select which you will use. In this case, Write-Output has only one parameter set, so you don't need to select one.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Write-Output properties</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Write-Output properties</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select the InputObject parameter.
trans-unit.target: Select the InputObject parameter.

trans-unit.source: This is the parameter where we will specify the text to send to the output stream.
trans-unit.target: This is the parameter where we will specify the text to send to the output stream.

trans-unit.source: In the Data source dropdown, select PowerShell expression.
trans-unit.target: In the Data source dropdown, select PowerShell expression.

trans-unit.source: The Data source dropdown provides different sources that you use to populate a parameter value.
trans-unit.target: The Data source dropdown provides different sources that you use to populate a parameter value.

trans-unit.source: You can use output from such sources such as another activity, an Automation asset, or a PowerShell expression.
trans-unit.target: You can use output from such sources such as another activity, an Automation asset, or a PowerShell expression.

trans-unit.source: In this case, we just want to output the text Hello World.
trans-unit.target: In this case, we just want to output the text Hello World.

trans-unit.source: We can use a PowerShell expression and specify a string.
trans-unit.target: We can use a PowerShell expression and specify a string.

trans-unit.source: In the Expression box, type "Hello World" and then click OK twice to return to the canvas.
trans-unit.target: In the Expression box, type "Hello World" and then click OK twice to return to the canvas.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>PowerShell Expression</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>PowerShell Expression</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Save the runbook by clicking Save.
trans-unit.target: Save the runbook by clicking Save.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Save runbook</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Save runbook</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Step 3 - Test the runbook
trans-unit.target: Step 3 - Test the runbook

trans-unit.source: Before we publish the runbook to make it available in production, we want to test it to make sure that it works properly.
trans-unit.target: Before we publish the runbook to make it available in production, we want to test it to make sure that it works properly.

trans-unit.source: When you test a runbook, you run its Draft version and view its output interactively.
trans-unit.target: When you test a runbook, you run its Draft version and view its output interactively.

trans-unit.source: Click Test pane to open the Test pane.
trans-unit.target: Click Test pane to open the Test pane.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Test pane</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Test pane</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Start to start the test.
trans-unit.target: Click Start to start the test.

trans-unit.source: This should be the only enabled option.
trans-unit.target: This should be the only enabled option.

trans-unit.source: A <link><linkText>runbook job</linkText><title></title></link> is created and its status displayed in the pane.
trans-unit.target: A <link><linkText>runbook job</linkText><title></title></link> is created and its status displayed in the pane.

trans-unit.source: The job status will start as Queued indicating that it is waiting for a runbook worker in the cloud to come available.
trans-unit.target: The job status will start as Queued indicating that it is waiting for a runbook worker in the cloud to come available.

trans-unit.source: It will then move to Starting when a worker claims the job, and then Running when the runbook actually starts running.
trans-unit.target: It will then move to Starting when a worker claims the job, and then Running when the runbook actually starts running.

trans-unit.source: When the runbook job completes, its output is displayed. In our case, we should see Hello World.
trans-unit.target: When the runbook job completes, its output is displayed. In our case, we should see Hello World.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Hello World</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Hello World</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Close the Test pane to return to the canvas.
trans-unit.target: Close the Test pane to return to the canvas.

trans-unit.source: Step 4 - Publish and start the runbook
trans-unit.target: Step 4 - Publish and start the runbook

trans-unit.source: The runbook that we just created is still in Draft mode.
trans-unit.target: The runbook that we just created is still in Draft mode.

trans-unit.source: We need to publish it before we can run it in production.
trans-unit.target: We need to publish it before we can run it in production.

trans-unit.source: When you publish a runbook, you overwrite the existing Published version with the Draft version.
trans-unit.target: When you publish a runbook, you overwrite the existing Published version with the Draft version.

trans-unit.source: In our case, we don't have a Published version yet because we just created the runbook.
trans-unit.target: In our case, we don't have a Published version yet because we just created the runbook.

trans-unit.source: Click Publish to publish the runbook and then Yes when prompted.
trans-unit.target: Click Publish to publish the runbook and then Yes when prompted.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish</linkText>

trans-unit.source: If you scroll left to view the runbook in the Runbooks pane now, it will show an Authoring Status of Published.
trans-unit.target: If you scroll left to view the runbook in the Runbooks pane now, it will show an Authoring Status of Published.

trans-unit.source: Scroll back to the right to view the pane for MyFirstRunbook.
trans-unit.target: Scroll back to the right to view the pane for MyFirstRunbook.

trans-unit.source: The options across the top allow us to start the runbook, schedule it to start at some time in the future, or create a <link><linkText>webhook</linkText><title></title></link> so it can be started through an HTTP call.
trans-unit.target: The options across the top allow us to start the runbook, schedule it to start at some time in the future, or create a <link><linkText>webhook</linkText><title></title></link> so it can be started through an HTTP call.

trans-unit.source: We just want to start the runbook so click Start and then Yes when prompted.
trans-unit.target: We just want to start the runbook so click Start and then Yes when prompted.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Start runbook</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Start runbook</linkText>

trans-unit.source: A job pane is opened for the runbook job that we just created.
trans-unit.target: A job pane is opened for the runbook job that we just created.

trans-unit.source: We can close this pane, but in this case we'll leave it open so we can watch the job's progress.
trans-unit.target: We can close this pane, but in this case we'll leave it open so we can watch the job's progress.

trans-unit.source: The job status is shown in Job Summary and matches the statuses that we saw when we tested the runbook.
trans-unit.target: The job status is shown in Job Summary and matches the statuses that we saw when we tested the runbook.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Job Summary</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Job Summary</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Once the runbook status shows Completed, click Output. The Output pane is opened, and we can see our Hello World.
trans-unit.target: Once the runbook status shows Completed, click Output. The Output pane is opened, and we can see our Hello World.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Job Summary</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Job Summary</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Close the Output pane.
trans-unit.target: Close the Output pane.

trans-unit.source: Click Streams to open the Streams pane for the runbook job. We should only see Hello World in the output stream, but this can show other streams for a runbook job such as Verbose and Error if the runbook writes to them.
trans-unit.target: Click Streams to open the Streams pane for the runbook job. We should only see Hello World in the output stream, but this can show other streams for a runbook job such as Verbose and Error if the runbook writes to them.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Job Summary</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Job Summary</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Close the Streams pane and the Job pane to return to the MyFirstRunbook pane.
trans-unit.target: Close the Streams pane and the Job pane to return to the MyFirstRunbook pane.

trans-unit.source: Click Jobs to open the Jobs pane for this runbook. This lists all of the jobs created by this runbook. We should only see one job listed since we only ran the job once.
trans-unit.target: Click Jobs to open the Jobs pane for this runbook. This lists all of the jobs created by this runbook. We should only see one job listed since we only ran the job once.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Jobs</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Jobs</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can click on this job to open the same Job pane that we viewed when we started the runbook.
trans-unit.target: You can click on this job to open the same Job pane that we viewed when we started the runbook.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to go back in time and view the details of any job that was created for a particular runbook.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to go back in time and view the details of any job that was created for a particular runbook.

trans-unit.source: Step 5 - Add authentication to manage Azure resources
trans-unit.target: Step 5 - Add authentication to manage Azure resources

trans-unit.source: We've tested and published our runbook, but so far it doesn't do anything useful.
trans-unit.target: We've tested and published our runbook, but so far it doesn't do anything useful.

trans-unit.source: We want to have it manage Azure resources.
trans-unit.target: We want to have it manage Azure resources.

trans-unit.source: It won't be able to do that though unless we have it authenticate using the credentials that are referred to in the <link><linkText>prerequisites</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: It won't be able to do that though unless we have it authenticate using the credentials that are referred to in the <link><linkText>prerequisites</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: We do that with the Set-AzureAccount cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: We do that with the Set-AzureAccount cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Open the graphical editor by clicking Edit on the MyFirstRunbook pane.
trans-unit.target: Open the graphical editor by clicking Edit on the MyFirstRunbook pane.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Edit runbook</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Edit runbook</linkText>

trans-unit.source: We don't need the Write Hello World to output anymore, so right click it and select Delete.
trans-unit.target: We don't need the Write Hello World to output anymore, so right click it and select Delete.

trans-unit.source: In the Library control, expand Cmdlets and then Azure.
trans-unit.target: In the Library control, expand Cmdlets and then Azure.

trans-unit.source: Add Add-AzureAccount to the canvas.
trans-unit.target: Add Add-AzureAccount to the canvas.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add-AzureAccount</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add-AzureAccount</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select Add-AzureAccount and then click Parameters in the Configuration pane.
trans-unit.target: Select Add-AzureAccount and then click Parameters in the Configuration pane.

trans-unit.source: Add-AzureAccount has multiple parameter sets, so we need to select one before we can provide parameter values.
trans-unit.target: Add-AzureAccount has multiple parameter sets, so we need to select one before we can provide parameter values.

trans-unit.source: Click Parameter Set and then select the User parameter set.
trans-unit.target: Click Parameter Set and then select the User parameter set.

trans-unit.source: Once you select the parameter set, the parameters are displayed in the Activity Parameter Configuration pane. Click Credential.
trans-unit.target: Once you select the parameter set, the parameters are displayed in the Activity Parameter Configuration pane. Click Credential.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add Azure account parameters</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add Azure account parameters</linkText>

trans-unit.source: We want this cmdlet to use a credential asset in our Automation account so select Credential asset for the Data source.
trans-unit.target: We want this cmdlet to use a credential asset in our Automation account so select Credential asset for the Data source.

trans-unit.source: Select the credential asset that has access to start and stop a virtual machine in your Azure environment.<html></html>
trans-unit.target: Select the credential asset that has access to start and stop a virtual machine in your Azure environment.<html></html>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Add Azure account data source</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Add Azure account data source</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click OK twice to return to the canvas.
trans-unit.target: Click OK twice to return to the canvas.

trans-unit.source: Step 6 - Add activity to start a virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Step 6 - Add activity to start a virtual machine

trans-unit.source: We'll now add a Start-AzureVM activity to start a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: We'll now add a Start-AzureVM activity to start a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: You can pick any virtual machine in your Azure subscription, and for now we'll be hardcoding that name into the cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can pick any virtual machine in your Azure subscription, and for now we'll be hardcoding that name into the cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Expand Cmdlets and then Azure.
trans-unit.target: Expand Cmdlets and then Azure.

trans-unit.source: Add Start-AzureVM to the canvas and then click and drag it underneath Add-AzureAccount.
trans-unit.target: Add Start-AzureVM to the canvas and then click and drag it underneath Add-AzureAccount.

trans-unit.source: Hover over Add-AzureAccount until a circle appears on the bottom of the shape.
trans-unit.target: Hover over Add-AzureAccount until a circle appears on the bottom of the shape.

trans-unit.source: Click the circle and drag the arrow to Start-AzureVM.
trans-unit.target: Click the circle and drag the arrow to Start-AzureVM.

trans-unit.source: The arrow that you just created is a link. The runbook will start with Add-AzureAccount and then run Start-AzureVM.
trans-unit.target: The arrow that you just created is a link. The runbook will start with Add-AzureAccount and then run Start-AzureVM.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Start-AzureVM</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Start-AzureVM</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select Start-AzureVM.
trans-unit.target: Select Start-AzureVM.

trans-unit.source: Click Parameters and then Parameter Set to view the sets for Start-AzureVM.
trans-unit.target: Click Parameters and then Parameter Set to view the sets for Start-AzureVM.

trans-unit.source: Select the ByName parameter set.
trans-unit.target: Select the ByName parameter set.

trans-unit.source: Note that Name and ServiceName have exclamation points next them.
trans-unit.target: Note that Name and ServiceName have exclamation points next them.

trans-unit.source: This indicates that they are required parameters.
trans-unit.target: This indicates that they are required parameters.

trans-unit.source: Select Name.
trans-unit.target: Select Name.

trans-unit.source: Use Constant value for the Data source and type in the name of the virtual machine to start.
trans-unit.target: Use Constant value for the Data source and type in the name of the virtual machine to start.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: Select ServiceName. Use Constant value for the Data source and type in the name of the virtual machine to start. Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Select ServiceName. Use Constant value for the Data source and type in the name of the virtual machine to start. Click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Start-AzureVM Parameters</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Start-AzureVM Parameters</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Click Test pane so that we can test the runbook.
trans-unit.target: Click Test pane so that we can test the runbook.

trans-unit.source: Click Start to start the test.
trans-unit.target: Click Start to start the test.

trans-unit.source: Once it completes, check that the virtual machine was started.
trans-unit.target: Once it completes, check that the virtual machine was started.

trans-unit.source: Step 7 - Add an input parameter to the runbook
trans-unit.target: Step 7 - Add an input parameter to the runbook

trans-unit.source: Our runbook currently starts the virtual machine that we specified in the Start-AzureVM cmdlet, but our runbook would be more useful if we could specify the virtual machine when the runbook is started.
trans-unit.target: Our runbook currently starts the virtual machine that we specified in the Start-AzureVM cmdlet, but our runbook would be more useful if we could specify the virtual machine when the runbook is started.

trans-unit.source: We will now add an input parameter to the runbook to provide that functionality.
trans-unit.target: We will now add an input parameter to the runbook to provide that functionality.

trans-unit.source: Open the graphical editor by clicking Edit on the MyFirstRunbook pane.
trans-unit.target: Open the graphical editor by clicking Edit on the MyFirstRunbook pane.

trans-unit.source: Click Input and output and then Add input to open the Runbook Input Parameter pane.
trans-unit.target: Click Input and output and then Add input to open the Runbook Input Parameter pane.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Runbook Input and Output</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Runbook Input and Output</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Specify VMName for the Name.
trans-unit.target: Specify VMName for the Name.

trans-unit.source: Keep string for the Type, but change Mandatory to Yes.
trans-unit.target: Keep string for the Type, but change Mandatory to Yes.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: Create a second mandatory input parameter called VMServiceName and then click OK to close the Input and Output pane.
trans-unit.target: Create a second mandatory input parameter called VMServiceName and then click OK to close the Input and Output pane.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Runbook Input Parameters</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Runbook Input Parameters</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select the Start-AzureVM activity and then click Parameters.
trans-unit.target: Select the Start-AzureVM activity and then click Parameters.

trans-unit.source: Change the Data source for Name to Runbook input and then select VMName.
trans-unit.target: Change the Data source for Name to Runbook input and then select VMName.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Start-AzureVM Name Parameter</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Start-AzureVM Name Parameter</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Change the Data source for ServiceName to Runbook input and then select VMServiceName.
trans-unit.target: Change the Data source for ServiceName to Runbook input and then select VMServiceName.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Start-AzureVM Parameters</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Start-AzureVM Parameters</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Save the runbook and open the Test pane.
trans-unit.target: Save the runbook and open the Test pane.

trans-unit.source: Note that you can now provide values for the two input variables that will be used in the test.
trans-unit.target: Note that you can now provide values for the two input variables that will be used in the test.

trans-unit.source: Close the Test pane.
trans-unit.target: Close the Test pane.

trans-unit.source: Click Publish to publish the new version of the runbook.
trans-unit.target: Click Publish to publish the new version of the runbook.

trans-unit.source: Stop the virtual machine that you started in the previous step.
trans-unit.target: Stop the virtual machine that you started in the previous step.

trans-unit.source: Click Start to start the runbook. Type in the VMName and VMServiceName for the virtual machine that you're going to start.
trans-unit.target: Click Start to start the runbook. Type in the VMName and VMServiceName for the virtual machine that you're going to start.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Start Runbook</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Start Runbook</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When the runbook completes, check that the virtual machine was started.
trans-unit.target: When the runbook completes, check that the virtual machine was started.

trans-unit.source: Step 8 - Create a conditional link
trans-unit.target: Step 8 - Create a conditional link

trans-unit.source: We will now modify the runbook so that it will only attempt to start the runbook if it is not already started.
trans-unit.target: We will now modify the runbook so that it will only attempt to start the runbook if it is not already started.

trans-unit.source: We'll do this by adding a Get-AzureVM cmdlet to the runbook that will include the current state of the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: We'll do this by adding a Get-AzureVM cmdlet to the runbook that will include the current state of the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: We'll then add a conditional link that will only run Start-AzureVM if the current running state is stopped.
trans-unit.target: We'll then add a conditional link that will only run Start-AzureVM if the current running state is stopped.

trans-unit.source: If the runbook isn't stopped, then output a message.
trans-unit.target: If the runbook isn't stopped, then output a message.

trans-unit.source: Open MyFirstRunbook in the graphical editor.
trans-unit.target: Open MyFirstRunbook in the graphical editor.

trans-unit.source: Remove the link between Add-AzureAccount and Start-AzureVM by clicking on it and then pressing the Delete key.
trans-unit.target: Remove the link between Add-AzureAccount and Start-AzureVM by clicking on it and then pressing the Delete key.

trans-unit.source: In the Library control, expand Cmdlets and then Azure.
trans-unit.target: In the Library control, expand Cmdlets and then Azure.

trans-unit.source: Add Get-AzureVM to the canvas.
trans-unit.target: Add Get-AzureVM to the canvas.

trans-unit.source: Create a link from Add-AzureAccount to Get-AzureVM. Create another link from Get-AzureVM to Start-AzureVM.
trans-unit.target: Create a link from Add-AzureAccount to Get-AzureVM. Create another link from Get-AzureVM to Start-AzureVM.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Runbook with Get-AzureVM</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Runbook with Get-AzureVM</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select Get-AzureVM and click Parameters.
trans-unit.target: Select Get-AzureVM and click Parameters.

trans-unit.source: Select the parameter set GetVMByServiceAndVMName.
trans-unit.target: Select the parameter set GetVMByServiceAndVMName.

trans-unit.source: For Name, set the Date source to Runbook input and then select VMName.
trans-unit.target: For Name, set the Date source to Runbook input and then select VMName.

trans-unit.source: For ServiceName, set the Date source to Runbook input and then select VMServiceName.
trans-unit.target: For ServiceName, set the Date source to Runbook input and then select VMServiceName.

trans-unit.source: Select the link between Get-AzureVM and Start-AzureVM.
trans-unit.target: Select the link between Get-AzureVM and Start-AzureVM.

trans-unit.source: In the Configuration pane, change Apply condition to True.
trans-unit.target: In the Configuration pane, change Apply condition to True.

trans-unit.source: Note that the link turns to a dashed line indicating that the target activity will only be run if the condition resolves to true.
trans-unit.target: Note that the link turns to a dashed line indicating that the target activity will only be run if the condition resolves to true.

trans-unit.source: For the Condition expression, type $ActivityOutput['Get-AzureVM'].PowerState -eq "Stopped". Start-AzureVM will now only run if the virtual machine is stopped.
trans-unit.target: For the Condition expression, type $ActivityOutput['Get-AzureVM'].PowerState -eq "Stopped". Start-AzureVM will now only run if the virtual machine is stopped.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Link condition</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Link condition</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Library control, expand Cmdlets and then Microsoft.PowerShell.Utility.
trans-unit.target: In the Library control, expand Cmdlets and then Microsoft.PowerShell.Utility.

trans-unit.source: Add Write-Output to the canvas.
trans-unit.target: Add Write-Output to the canvas.

trans-unit.source: Create a link from Get-AzureVM to Write-Output.
trans-unit.target: Create a link from Get-AzureVM to Write-Output.

trans-unit.source: Select the link and change Apply condition to True.
trans-unit.target: Select the link and change Apply condition to True.

trans-unit.source: For the Condition expression, type $ActivityOutput['Get-AzureVM'].PowerState -ne "Stopped". Write-Output will now only run if the virtual machine is not stopped.
trans-unit.target: For the Condition expression, type $ActivityOutput['Get-AzureVM'].PowerState -ne "Stopped". Write-Output will now only run if the virtual machine is not stopped.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Runbook with Write-Output</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Runbook with Write-Output</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select Write-Output and click Parameters.
trans-unit.target: Select Write-Output and click Parameters.

trans-unit.source: For InputObject, change Data source to PowerShell expression and type in the expression "$VMName.Name already started.".
trans-unit.target: For InputObject, change Data source to PowerShell expression and type in the expression "$VMName.Name already started.".

trans-unit.source: Save the runbook and open the Test pane.
trans-unit.target: Save the runbook and open the Test pane.

trans-unit.source: Start the runbook with the virtual machine stopped, and it should start.
trans-unit.target: Start the runbook with the virtual machine stopped, and it should start.

trans-unit.source: Start the runbook with the virtual machine started, and you should get output that it is already started.
trans-unit.target: Start the runbook with the virtual machine started, and you should get output that it is already started.

trans-unit.source: Related articles
trans-unit.target: Related articles

trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Graphical authoring in Azure Automation</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>My first textual runbook</linkText><title></title></link>
